case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. M/s Alps Theatre

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated October 28, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in I.T. Reference No. 28 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 26 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 28, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in I. T. Reference No. 28 of 1962.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal, Delhi Bench C, referred the question at the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax,, the Appellate Tribunal, Delhi Bench C, referred the following question Whether the companyt of land is entitled to depreciation under the schedule to the Income- tax Act alongwith the companyt of the building standing thereon.?

facts.text: The respondent, M/s Alps Theatre, carries on business as exhibitor of films.

anchor.surface_text: This question arose out of the following facts The respon- dent, M s Alps Theatre, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, carries on business as exhibitor of films.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer initiated proceedings under s. 34(1)(b) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer initiated proceedings under s. 34 1  b  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, on the ground that in the original assessment depreciation was allowed on the entire companyt of Rs. 85,091/-,

facts.text: In the original assessment, depreciation was allowed on the entire cost of Rs. 85,091/-, shown as cost of the building which included Rs. 12,000/- as cost of land.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that in the original assessment depreciation was allowed on the entire companyt of Rs. 85,091/-, shown as companyt ,of the building which included Rs. 12,000/- as companyt of land.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer, by his order dated February 22, 1959, recomputed the depreciation, excluding cost of land.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer, by his order dated February 22, 1959, recomputed the depreciation, excluding companyt of land.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee ap- pealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal which accepted the appeal.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal accepted the assessee's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal which accepted the appeal.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal observed that a building cannot be conceived without the land beneath it.

anchor.surface_text: In accepting the appeal it observed as follows You cannot companyceive of a building without the land beneath it. It is number possible to companyceive of a building without a bottom.

facts.text: The High Court answered the question referred to it against the Department.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question referred to it against the Department.

facts.text: Mahajan, J., observed that in Section 10(2)(vi) of the Income Tax Act, a building is placed at par with machinery and furniture and is treated as a unit.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan, J., observed that in Section 10 2  vi  of the Income Tax Act, a building is placed at par with machinery and furniture and is treated as a unit, and, therefore, for the purposes of depreciation a building cannot be split up into building material and land.

facts.text: The question referred is whether the cost of land is entitled to depreciation under the schedule to the Income-tax Act along with the cost of the building standing thereon.

anchor.surface_text: the following question Whether the companyt of land is entitled to depreciation under the schedule to the Income- tax Act alongwith the companyt of the building standing thereon.?

arguments.court_reasoning: Building excludes land as per harmonious construction, depreciation definition, and rules.

arguments.claim: Section 10(2)(vi) allows depreciation on the building, and 'building' connotes the land upon which something has been constructed.

anchor.surface_text: What Section  10   2   vi  of the Act says is that depreciation will be allowed on the building. The word building itself companynotes the land upon which something has been companystructed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Word 'building' has consistent meaning excluding land across related clauses; land does not depreciate.

arguments.claim: It was wrong to exclude value of land; true meaning of building includes land upon which construction made; two must go together.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, wrong on the part of the authorities below to exclude the value of the land upon which some companystruction was made. The true meaning of the word building means the land upon which some companystruction has been made. The two must necessarily go together.

arguments.court_reasoning: Absurd consequences if land depreciates at varying rates per structure class.

arguments.claim: In Section 10(2)(vi), building placed at par with machinery and furniture, treated as unit; cannot split into material and land for depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan, J., observed that in Section 10 2  vi  of the Income Tax Act, a building is placed at par with machinery and furniture and is treated as a unit, and, therefore, for the purposes of depreciation a building cannot be split up into building material and land.

arguments.court_reasoning: Contextual interpretation from other clauses and rules shows exclusion.

arguments.claim: Depreciation allowed on capital which is unit building; if sold for more than WDV, surplus taxed u/s 10(2)(vii) proviso.

anchor.surface_text: He then added Moreover, depreciation is allowed on the capital. The capital here is a unit building. If later on it is sold and it fetches more than its written down value the surplus is liable to tax see in this companynection Section 10 2   vii  proviso.

arguments.claim: Building treated as unit for depreciation or repair; no warrant in Act to split unit for s.10.

anchor.surface_text: He felt that the crux of the matter is that the building is treated as a unit for purposes of depreciation or repair, and there is numberwarrant in the Act which would permit us to split the unit for the purposes of section IO.

anchor.surface_text: He further felt that at any rate two equally plausible interpretations are possible and the one in favour of the assessee should be adopted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Clear meaning from context favours exclusion of land.

arguments.claim: Question not free from difficulty; much can be said for both views; Tribunal view not clearly erroneous; favour assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Dua, J., in a companycurring judgment, felt that the question was number free from difficulty, but he answered the question in favour of the assessee on the ground that much companyld be said for both points of view and the view in support of the assessees submission had found favour with the Tribunal which had number been shown to be clearly erroneous.

arguments.claim: Word 'building' must have same meaning in sub-clauses (iv),(v),(vi),(vi-a),(vii) of s.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clauses  iv ,  v ,  vi ,  vi-a  and  vii  of S. 10 2  deal with allowances in respect of buildings, machinery, plant or furniture. The word building must have the same meaning in all these clauses.

arguments.claim: Sub-clause (iv): insurance against damage/destruction of buildings; site cannot be destroyed, so excludes land.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause  iv  runs as under in respect of insurance against risk of damage or destruction of buildings, machinery, plant, furniture,stocks or stores, used for the purpose of the business,profession or vocation, the amount of any premium paid. Building here clearly, it seems to us, does number include the site because there cannot be any question of destruction of the site.

arguments.claim: Depreciation in s.10(2)(vi) means decrease in value through wear etc.; land cannot depreciate.

anchor.surface_text: It would be numbericed that the word used is depreciation and depreciation means a decrease in value of property through wear, deterioration, or obsolescence the allowance made for this in book-keeping, accounting, etc.  Websters New World Dictionary . In that sense land cannot depreciate.

arguments.claim: Rule 8 IT Rules 1922 prescribes depreciation rates for classes of buildings (structures), excluding land.
Depreciation rates vary by class of structure; land under inferior building depreciating faster is absurd.
Object of s.10 is true assessable income; depreciation per accountancy principles; allowing on land distorts true income.
High Court relied on Corporation of the City of Victoria case is distinguishable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on Corporation of the City of Victoria and Bishop of Vancouver Island  , but in our view this case is distinguishable and gives numberassistance in determining the meaning of the word buildings in the companytext of S. 10 2  vi .

holdings.text: The cost of land is not entitled to depreciation under the schedule to the Income-tax Act along with the cost of the building standing thereon.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the companyt of land is entitled to depreciation under the schedule to the Income- tax Act alongwith the companyt of the building standing thereon.?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'building' in S.10(2)(vi) via harmonious construction with other clauses, depreciation definition excluding land, Rule 8 rates for structures, absurdity of varying land rates, and purpose of true income computation.

holdings.text: The word 'building' occurring in Section 10(2)(vi) does not include land.

anchor.surface_text: tion of S. 10 2  vi , and in particular whether the word building occurring in it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction requires same meaning across S.10(2) sub-clauses (iv-vii); excludes site in insurance (iv) and repairs (v); land cannot depreciate per definition; supported by Rule 8 and true income purpose.

holdings.text: The word 'building' must have the same meaning in sub-clauses (iv), (v), (vi), (vi-a) and (vii) of S.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clauses  iv ,  v ,  vi ,  vi-a  and  vii  of S. 10 2  deal with allowances in respect of buildings, machinery, plant or furniture. The word building must have the same meaning in all these clauses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of harmonious construction applied to related allowances for buildings etc.

holdings.text: In sub-clause (iv) of S.10(2), 'building' does not include the site because there cannot be any question of destruction of the site.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause  iv  runs as under in respect of insurance against risk of damage or destruction of buildings, machinery, plant, furniture,stocks or stores, used for the purpose of the business,profession or vocation, the amount of any premium paid. Building here clearly, it seems to us, does number include the site because there cannot be any question of destruction of the site.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: insurance against damage/destruction inapplicable to land/site.

holdings.text: In clause (v) of S.10(2), 'building' does not include the site as it cannot be subject to current repairs.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  v  reads in respect of current repairs to such buildings, machinery, plant or furniture, the amount paid on account thereof. This again cannot include the site.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: repairs inapplicable to land/site.

holdings.text: Land cannot depreciate as depreciation means decrease in value through wear, deterioration, or obsolescence.

anchor.surface_text: It would be numbericed that the word used is depreciation and depreciation means a decrease in value of property through wear, deterioration, or obsolescence the allowance made for this in book-keeping, accounting, etc.  Websters New World Dictionary . In that sense land cannot depreciate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning/definition of depreciation excludes land.

holdings.text: Rule 8 of the Indian Income Tax Rules, 1922 confirms that 'buildings' for depreciation means structures excluding land, with rates based on class of structure.

anchor.surface_text: That this is the proper meaning is also borne out by r. 8 of the Indian Income Tax Rules, 1922. Rule 8 has a schedule, and as far as buildings are companycerned, it reads as under Class of asset Rate per- Remarks centage Buildings - First class substantial buildings of materials 2.5 Double these numbers Scond class building will be taken for factory of less substantial company- 5 buildings excluding struction offices,godowns,officers

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule prescribes rates for building classes (structures); no rate for land; renewals for temporary as revenue.

holdings.text: Allowing depreciation on land would lead to absurdity, e.g., land under third class building depreciating faster than under first class.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy consequence: varying depreciation rates for land based on overlying structure illogical.

holdings.text: The object of S.10 is to arrive at true assessable income; depreciation allowable per accountancy and Act, but not on land as it does not depreciate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive: reflects real income; land depreciation distorts.

holdings.text: Corporation of the City of Victoria case is distinguishable and does not assist in interpreting 'buildings' in S.10(2)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on Corporation of the City of Victoria and Bishop of Vancouver Island  , but in our view this case is distinguishable and gives numberassistance in determining the meaning of the word buildings in the companytext of S. 10 2  vi .
